content: Skills are the apps in Software 3.0, and skills stores will be the new App Stores.
Skills registries don't win without owning or connecting to a local desktop application that users use daily.
Apple won distribution not by building a better catalog, but by controlling the end-user compute surface.
Once you own the surface for compute, you dominate the distribution of software.

The agent landscape can be mapped to the App Store model: Apps = Skills (reusable bundles of instructions), Hardware = User-facing application controlling distribution (desktop client, terminal UI, chat interface), OS = Agent harness (runtime that executes skills and mediates between user and model).
Generic skills that run on any harness are commodities.
If a platform develops high-quality, deeply-integrated skills that take advantage of its specific runtime capabilities, those become reasons to stay.
The App Store's moat isn't just that it has apps; it's that developers build for iOS first because of the specific capabilities and economics of that ecosystem.
When skills, memory, automations, and connected services all live in one place, the switching cost is the sum of all of them, not any single feature.
Apple locks users in not with any one product, but with the interplay between iCloud, AirDrop, Handoff, iMessage, and the App Store, similar to how a unified platform creates high switching costs.

A scenario I see happening is Codex Desktop or Claude Code Cowork shipping with a suite of integrated tools (markdown editor, macOS/Windows launcher, linear, screenshot taker, meeting notetaker, lightweight code editor, 1Password), allowing the Agent to automatically get all user context on the fly.
We are in a weird time where Apps (Skills) are popping out and being indexed on all kinds of websites without a dominant hardware (desktop app) that knits them together.
No one has locked in enough users through a combination of daily-driver UX, personal memory, and proprietary skills to own the distribution layer the way Apple owns mobile.
There's a huge opportunity to build a dominant distribution layer for AI skills.
It's unclear who will build the dominant distribution layer for AI skills, whether it's big labs, big tech, or emerging startups.
In early stages of a new paradigm shift, no one knows much more than others, creating a great equalizer and opportunity for startups.
